part of the gusset the needle and marker set-up once you start the colour work is as follows bor to ssm1 4 sts side stripe ssm1 to ssm2 28 32 36 sts section 1 instep leg front and back ssm2 to ssm3 4 sts side stripe ssm3 to gm1 11 13 15 sts section 2a gm1 to gm2 6 sts centre sole stripe sole gm2 to bor 11 13 15 sts section 2b the bor is at the beginning of the side stripe before the instep colour work knitting when knitting stranded colour work be consistent with your strand orientation if your mc crosses above your cc at the back of your work keep it that way throughout your project ɸ working your socks inside out helps with better gauge/float lengths ɸ lbj is a good technique for catching long floats and allowing stretch ɸ it is generally recommended to catch floats longer than 2 5 cm/1 inch personally i find these floats too long and prefer to catch floats every 3-5 stitches how many stitches you have before catching a float is up to you when making increases in colour work lift the bar of the same colour yarn as you are making the increase with this pattern is for personal use only ©lorraine rayson 2024 s-64 m-72 l-80 searching for king sexred-toe up-v01-230824 page 2 / 27 charts all charts have fully written instructions there are two sets of charts one set with dark mc light motifs and the other set with light mc dark motifs gusset charts there are 3 sizes to choose from depending on your personal preference choose a size gusset you prefer for fit the small gusset chart is the standard size gusset for the size small sock same applies for other sizes you can mix and match any gusset chart regardless of what size socks you are working if you are knitting size small or medium and you need more room in the instep area then you may wish to use a larger gusset chart if you are knitting sizes medium or large and you need less room in the instep area then you may wish to use a smaller gusset chart motif charts 2 there are 11 different charts for you to choose from examples of how each motif looks repeated/knitted is provided on p 11 mix and match which charts you use throughout your socks use every chart or repeat charts as wanted/needed work the same charts on both socks same or different order for a matching or near matching pair work different charts on each sock if you do this you will need to do a little maths to make sure your socks are about
